claim: Recombinant HA antigens produced using BEVS have been shown to induce significantly higher levels of broadly cross-reactive antibodies against highly conserved regions of HA compared with egg-derived vaccines.
explanation: Four-panel bar/point plot showing geometric mean fold rise in antibody titers 1 month post-vaccination (panels A and B for ages 18–44 and 45–64) and geometric mean fold reduction in titers from 1 to 6 months (panels C and D) against individual influenza strains (H3N2 egg, H3N2 cell, H1N1 egg, H1N1 cell, B/VIC egg, B/VIC cell, B/YAM egg, B/YAM cell). Four vaccine groups are compared: FluZone IIV4 (open circles), Fluarix IIV4 (closed circles), cell-culture IIV4 (green), and recombinant HA (RIV4, orange). P values are shown for pairwise comparisons of fold rises or reductions between vaccines for each strain and age group. The figure presents strain-specific antibody titer fold rises and waning for different vaccine formulations but does not measure or report broadly cross-reactive antibodies against conserved HA regions. It therefore does not support the claim. Note: Interpretation limited to what is visible; no data on cross-reactive or stem-specific antibody responses are shown.
